Lease payments are discounted using the implicit interest rate or the lessee's incremental borrowing rate.
Judgments are required regarding the length of the lease term and the discount rate.
Extensions are included in the lease term if there's reasonable certainty they will occur.
Leases under USD 5,000 and short-term contracts are recognized as expenses on a straight-line basis.
Leases are classified as operating leases for the Parent Company under RFR 2.

Duni Group

Major steps forward despite external challenges. Despite difficult external factors, we translated our updated strategy from words into action in 2022. Our sustainability initiatives and values give the business a purpose and help us on our way to becoming the industry's sustainability leader.
Group sales for the year totaled SEK 6,976 million (5,061) in 2022, which corresponds to a sales increase of 37.8%.
Operating income figure amounted to SEK 450 million (279).
BioPak business area increased by 23.9% compared with 2021.
Duni business area grew by 50.4% during the year.
External factors such as pandemic impact, war in Ukraine leading to inflation and rising costs of energy and raw materials were highlighted as concerns.
Efforts to prioritize sustainability and embed it in organizational operations.

data.value: The credit risk associated with accounts receivable that are neither overdue nor impaired is not normally considered to be large. The risk increased during the pandemic, resulting in a temporary higher risk of customer bankruptcies.

Pandemic negatively impacted the market in early 2022.
Germany faced longer restrictions compared to Nordic countries.
HoReCa sector has strongly recovered since the second quarter.
Duni area reported good results; BioPak area remained steady.
War in Ukraine caused rising energy prices and inflation.
Price increases likely to significantly impact future outcomes.
Circular models and Digitalization are key trends.
Duni Group's business is affected by various external factors and is constantly exposed to risks and threats.
Active risk management with analyses is undertaken systematically on an annual basis.
Employees in 21 countries with production in Sweden, Germany, Poland, Thailand and New Zealand.
Each country has unique challenges and risks with local regulations and laws that must be followed.
Group Management reports risk issues ongoing to the Board of Directors.
Goal is to identify, control and balance initiatives against financial and sustainability goals.
Foreign exchange, interest rate, liquidity and credit risks.
Environmental, human rights and corruption risks.
Impacts from Covid-19 pandemic, sharp rise in inflation, and the war in Ukraine.
Workshop
Identify and map
Probability and impact assessment
Prioritize
Manage, handle and remedy
Regulatory risks

Legal risks are identified throughout the business. These include changes in legislation, violations of legislation within the organization, deficiencies in agreements or legal challenges locally that might have negative legal and financial consequences for the company. Duni Group operates in many countries, and the varying legal requirements between countries can pose a risk.

There is a focus on legal changes and legal compliance within all business functions and countries. The business monitors legal changes regarding single-use products, plastics, and forest industry environmental impact. Works with external experts and advisors, governed by Duni Group's Code of Business Conduct.
Supplier dependency

Duni Group is dependent on external suppliers for manufacturing, selling and delivering products. Key dependencies include raw materials for tissue materials (Duni) and key suppliers in Asia and Europe (BioPak).

Risk managed by reducing dependence and spreading suppliers where possible. Work with supplier planning and evaluation of continuity plans. Geographic distribution and material choice considerations for traded goods.
Customer dependency
Duni Group sells to retail sector, e-commerce, end customers and wholesalers. Wholesaler performance affects earnings. Faces competition especially in German market.

Top 10 customers account for ~20% of net sales. Focus on long-term relationships and new customer development. Risk spread across many end customers through wholesaler structure. Innovation department develops eco-smart solutions to maintain competitiveness.
External risks
Exposed to external risks including Russia's invasion of Ukraine and sharp rise in inflation affecting material costs.
Monitored Ukraine developments, followed sanctions, divested Russian operations. No inputs or imports from Russia or Ukraine.
Disruption faci at production
The Group's paper mill in Skapafors supplies converting units with tissue and airlaid. Risks include fire, machine breakdown, handling errors, resource shortages, IT breakdown.
Active preventive measures, fire safety training, continuous maintenance, insurance cover, annual facility inspections, continuity plans.
Disruption logistics in the chain
Disruptions can occur internally and externally in logistics chain. Risks include cyber attacks, bankruptcy, fire, lack of personnel, machine breakdown affecting deliveries.
Preventive measures, efficient processes for transport provider replacement, flexible collaboration with logistics partners, fire prevention training.
Employee risks
Risks related to succession, discrimination, occupational health and safety, and skills retention.
Annual succession planning, employee discussions, skills development, health and safety measures, pulse surveys, whistleblower function.
Product safety
Strict requirements for food-contact products, rapid legal changes affecting product range.
Product safety testing, external expert collaboration, supplier training, focus on regulatory compliance.
IT security
Disruptions to critical IT systems, cyber security threats.
Continuous investment in technology, monitoring of developments.
Environmental impact
Duni Group's operations involve the consumption of natural resources and environmental emissions that can result in a negative environmental impact.

Duni Group's production units in Europe are environmentally certified and regular environmental inspections are conducted to identify any negative environmental effects that our operations give rise to.
Environmental impact
Risks such as emissions to nature, climate change, impacts on biodiversity, noise, and depletion of natural resources can thus affect how our operations can be conducted.

Emission controls, environmental goals (such as reducing the use of virgin fossil plastics) and the implementation of other measures to reduce our environmental impact are implemented in all parts of the business.
value chain

Some of Duni Group's products are produced in or purchased from countries where transparency concerning human rights is limited. This can mean risks of, for example, child labor, slavery, discrimination, or unsafe workplaces are not detected in time and workers in our value chain are mistreated.

Duni Group's codes of business conduct and supplementary policy documents apply to all employees, Board members and executives (incl. Group Management), suppliers and business partners. Compliance in the supply chain is followed up through audits.
Corruption

Corruption poses a threat to sustainable economic and social development around the world, and to varying degrees it exists globally. Duni Group operates in many countries and, like many other companies, runs the risk of involvement in corrupt and unethical behavior, fraud, and irregularities in sales, purchasing, and production.

Duni Group holds internal training courses in the company's Code of Business conduct. These are supplemented by detailed policy documents. All of the Group's employees, Board members, executives (incl. Group Management), suppliers and business partners undertake to comply with these policies.
Certifications

Duni Group has a number of sustainability-related certifications, such as the Forest Stewardship Council® (FSC®) and OK Compost. Risk factors, such as the changing of criterias, or the value chain not complying with the requirements, can contribute to a possible loss of the certifications.

Part of our sustainability work is devoted to living up to and maintaining our certifications. It is extremely important to have good internal control and to work actively on auditing both our own operations and the entire value chain.
Renewable energy

Duni Group's strategy is to have a net zero climate impact for Scope 1 & 2 by 2030. One step is to use renewable energy in production. A lack of renewable energy could have a negative impact on the environment and thereby also the company's strategy.

Clear key performance indicators (KPIs) are set in production. Work is also continuously under way to examine various solutions for energy reduction and switching to renewable energy in order to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. At the largest converting unit in Bramsche, Germany, as well as our sales office in Breda, the Netherlands, solar panels were installed in 2022.
Risk of errors financial
in reporting: There are risks to financial reporting, partly through handling errors or system errors, which affect access to relevant IT systems, and partly a lack of resources or other factors.
There are a number of mitigating measures including good internal control, clear reporting schedules, broad controller function, continuous system backups, and system priority at IT.
Currency risk

Includes transaction exposure (purchases and sales in different currencies) and translation exposure (when subsidiaries' statements are translated to SEK). Has major impact on Group's reported revenue and income.
Managed through concentration of exposure to few Group companies and Board-adopted financial policy. Internal measures exist but external factors affect risk.
Capital risk
Comprises refinancing and liquidity risks when company cannot meet payment obligations due to liquidity shortage or credit difficulties.
Managed by Group Treasury through cash availability, credit facilities, liquidity forecasts, and cash flow activities.
Interest rate risk
Exposure from variable interest rate borrowing and internal lending/borrowing at variable rates.
Managed through interest rate hedging using interest rate swaps for financial hedging, not speculation.
Credit risk
Risk of counterparty failing to fulfill commitments and causing losses.
Managed through external credit checks on customers and regulatory framework monitoring.
Taxes
Compliance with tax laws and regulations, with risk of negative consequences for non-compliance.
Managed through financial manual, external experts, and continuous interpretation of regulations.
Price risk
General exposure to price risks, with high inflation in 2022.
Focus on energy efficiency, balanced contracted/spot pricing, and transition towards biofuel energy mix.
The Group is exposed to various currency risks arising from international operations.
Risks associated with changes in energy prices, particularly gas and electricity.
Exposure to interest rate risks in cash flow and fair value.
Risks related to the possibility of default by counterparties.
Risks concerning the ability to meet cash flow needs.
Impact of translating income statements of subsidiaries from functional currency to SEK.
Risk arising from sales and purchases in currencies other than functional currency.
Production units experience risks from changes in energy prices.

As of January 1, 2020, the former business areas were discontinued and replaced by a functional organization with clear sales and marketing responsibilities. The new organization consists of two business areas: Duni and BioPak.

As of January 1, 2020, the former business areas were discontinued and replaced by a functional organization with clear sales and marketing responsibilities. The new organization consists of two business areas: Duni and BioPak.

A material known for its wetness allocation, absorption capability and softness. The process is based on using air to distribute the fibers in the material instead of water as in traditional tissue production. Airlaid is used for table covers, place-mats and napkins.

Bagasse is a waste product from cane sugar processing after the sugar has been extracted. The material is 100% biodegradable. Bagasse is mainly used in meal packaging and serving products such as plates, bowls and take-away boxes.
Sustainable premium table covers and placemats made from potato starch, produced by Duni's team in Germany.
Sustainable premium napkins made with ground-breaking BioBinder™ based on organic waste.
BRC and IFS are management systems for hygiene and food safety. The units in Bramsche and Poznan are BRC certified. The unit in Wolkenstein is IFS certified.

An integrated holistic approach to the sustainability-related challenges faced by the Group. It encompasses the whole life cycle - from material selection and impact on the life cycle, to ultimate solutions.
Tailoring solutions for specific customers so they reinforce the customer's own concept and brand.
Digital security, which protects digital information, networks, devices, applications and data from attack or unauthorized access through various methods.
Dunicel is a table cover based on a unique material with a fall similar to cloth. Thanks to a special production method, the feel is entirely different from ordinary paper table covers.
Duniform is a system for food and beverage distribution and covers everything from packaging machines to heat maintenance bags.
Dunilin feels and folds like linen and is used for the most luxurious napkins. A unique material with a woven effect to look like linen, but is based on paper pulp.
A package of policy initiatives to pave the way for a green transition in the EU, with the ultimate goal of climate neutrality by 2050.

Evolin is a new, revolutionary table covering material that combines the look and feel of textile and linen table covers with the advantages of the disposable product. It is a hybrid material based on cellulose fiber and produced with a patented process.
An internal hub to identify, test and validate different solutions that are outside the core business, but still targeting the HoReCa+ segment.

Abbreviation for Forest Stewardship Council, an independent membership organization that certifies forest management regarding social responsibility, environmental sustainability and economic viability.
The leading standard for business to measure, manage and report greenhouse gas emissions.
The Duni business area's brand platform - to create a pleasant atmosphere and positive mood at all times when food and drink are prepared and served - a Goodfoodmood.
Acronym for Hotel, Restaurant and Catering.

ISO 14001 is the only international standard for environmental management systems and has been chosen as a standard within Duni. Units in Bramsche, Poznan, Dals Langed and Skapafors are ISO 14001-certified.
ISO 26000 is an international standard that defines corporate social responsibility.
ISO 9001 is an international standard for quality management. The units in Bramsche, Wolkenstein, Poznan and Skapafors are ISO 9001 certified.
The production phase in which tissue and airlaid in large rolls are cut, pressed, embossed and folded into finished napkins and table covers.
A method for calculating the environmental impact of a product's entire life cycle - from the extraction of natural resources until the product is no longer used and must be disposed of.
The OK Compost label means that Duni has the world’s first and largest range of compostable napkins, both in single colors and in selected designs.
Growth excluding currency and structural effects. Acquired companies are included in organic growth when they have been a part of the Duni Group for five quarters.

Duni Group's updated strategy with a long-term vision, a higher purpose and a clear sustainability agenda based on UN Agenda 2030. With our 'Decade of Action', we want to lead the way in sustainability.
Products marketed under the customer's own brand.
Duni Sacchetto is a paper cutlery pocket with space for a napkin.
A framework that helps companies and organizations to set science-based climate targets that are in line with what is required to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement.
The UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are 17 priority areas where there is consensus on the need for significant improvements by 2030.
The EU's Single Use Plastics Directive, which aims to implement a series of measures for Member States to address the negative environmental impacts of certain plastic products.
The UN Global Compact (UNGC) is the world’s largest initiative to unite the business community around corporate sustainability, no matter how large or complex a company is or where it is located.
Figures adjusted for changes in exchange rates related to consolidation. Figures for 2022 are calculated at exchange rates for 2021. Effects of translation of balance sheet items are not included.
Vertical integration means that the Group, through the Duni business, owns virtually the entire value chain for tablecloths and napkins (tissue and airlaid).
An analysis with internal and external key stakeholders to ensure that sustainability work is based on relevant areas has formed the basis of our three sustainability initiatives.
